bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, August 3, 1937

div1.p: Andrus compliments Truby and requests verification of certain incidents related to the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, August 3, 1937
div1.opener:
J.H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
8-3-37
General A. E. Truby,
Washington, D. C.
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Dear General:
div1.p:
Have been tempted, many times, to write you but have
been able to resist until now that I have what might
pass as an excuse.

First, I want you to know how much I appreciate your
kindness to me when I was in Walter Reed Hospital -
from May 13, until Oct. 6, 1932.

Returned home on the latter date - after medicos had
concluded that they could never fix me up so that I
would be able to walk again.

Have been bedfast ever since returning. Thanks to
the Walter Reed annuity of $1,500. we are able to live
in comfort without having to draw too heavily on the
few dollars I had been able to accumulate.

Have been keeping in touch with yourvcareer, was very
much pleased at your elevation but disappointed when
you were retired without becoming Surgeon General.

You deserve - and I sincerely hope you have - many
years of excellent health in which to enjoy your re-
tirement. You are one of those rare individuals
who possess the faculty of maintaining discipline
and, at the same time, winning and holding the re-
spect and affection of the enlisted personnel.

This was true when I knew you in Cuba, as a first
lieutenant, and equally true when, as a colonel and
the C. O., you were head man at Walter Reed Hospital.

I also earnestly hope that you may not be called back
to active service. With affairs so muddled in
Europe and Asia it will be a miracle if there is not
another “world” war.

And now for that “excuse” for writing -
Page 2.
Am enclosing copy of a letter to the Secretary of War
in an effort to secure revision of that section of the
roll of honor (which appears in the Official Army
Register) applying to me.

You see my son (an M. D.) and his wife have just made
me a grandfather and - while the roll of honor, as it
stands, suits me - I would like to have the record
straight for those to whom I can not leave much else.

You will note that I have referred to you for verifi-
cation of a number of statements. Among them:
Duty with the Commission. - I may be wrong, but I have
always thought that you suggested me to Major Reed.
Someone did because he asked for me. You have
always seemed most likely. In any event I have no
doubt but that you remember that I was detailed for
duty in the laboratory. I do not mean at Camp
Lazear - but the shack which was the operating room
when the post hospital at Camp Columbia was in tents.
This is the layout:
Page 3.
H - Small addition in which guinea pigs were housed.

As regards the second point on which I refer to you for
fonfirmation: I feel quite confident that you know
of thisnincident. Forbes had yellow fever from
blood innoculation and the Major had Tom England lined
up to take an injection of Forbes' blood - to continue
the series of experiments.

England had slept in fomite building and was to have
taken mosquito-bite or blood innoculation but had a
change of heart.

There were other volunteers scheduled for other exper-
iments. Rather than disrupt the schedule Major
Reed decided to have Forbes' blood injected into him.
It had to be done quickly, as Forbes was getting better.
Lieutenant Carroll threw a fit and the Major held fast.
All this was threshed out in my presence in the lab.

“I SEEN MY DUTY - BUT I DIDN'T DONE IT” - I had seen
too much of yellow fever to want any.

The next morning the Major was still determined - then
I volunteered.

I believe every
word of this
A E T

I feel quite confident that Dr. Carroll called upon you
to help persuade the Major to give the idea up.

You may think I am doing a lot of guessing on all this
but don't forget that I heard Major Reed and Dr. Carroll
talking by the hour.

Please forgive me, General, for presuming on your kind-
ness to me in the past to burden you with all this.

And please accept my kindest regards and best wishes for
your future health, happiness and prosperity.
